courses.title: Filmmaking I
courses.description: Each student will make their own narrative short  with a maximum five minute run time.  Before  principal photography begins the class will focus  on script writing, pitching, production  management, risk management, crew  responsibilities, location sound recording, and  casting.  Upon completion of the production phase  students will screen and critique dailies, rough  cuts, and final cuts. Students will strengthen  their collaborative and storytelling skills.
courses.subject: Filmmaking
courses.prereq: Film majors only. Complete FLM-225 and FLM-230.

courses.title: Filmmaking I
courses.description: Each student will make their own narrative short  with a maximum five minute run time.  Before  principal photography begins the class will focus  on script writing, pitching, production  management, risk management, crew  responsibilities, location sound recording, and  casting.  Upon completion of the production phase  students will screen and critique dailies, rough  cuts, and final cuts. Students will strengthen  their collaborative and storytelling skills.
courses.subject: Filmmaking
courses.prereq: Film majors only. Complete FLM-225 and FLM-230.

courses.title: Cinematography and Lighting
courses.description: This course focuses on cinematic storytelling, and explores digital video cinematography techniques for both studio and field. Students will familiarize themselves with multiple digital video camera formats.  Students will also use lighting equipment, determine set and lighting needs, block scenes, and become familiar with topics including film space, continuity, lenses, color, filters, and camera control. Over the course of the semester, students will collaborate to produce a number of short works in both field and studio environments.
courses.subject: Filmmaking

courses.title: Cinematography and Lighting
courses.description: This course focuses on cinematic storytelling, and explores digital video cinematography techniques for both studio and field. Students will familiarize themselves with multiple digital video camera formats.  Students will also use lighting equipment, determine set and lighting needs, block scenes, and become familiar with topics including film space, continuity, lenses, color, filters, and camera control. Over the course of the semester, students will collaborate to produce a number of short works in both field and studio environments.
courses.subject: Filmmaking

courses.title: Topics in Cinema
courses.description: Topics in Cinema is a rotating-subject course designed to introduce students to a wide range of concepts within the field of film studies.  Its scope is broad and changes from semester to semester; topics may include but are not limited to the study of specific filmmakers, specific film genres, certain national cinemas, film movements, or other special topics.
courses.subject: Filmmaking
courses.prereq: This course is only open to film majors and film minors.  Film majors must complete FLM-210 or COR-2XX and complete 36 credits. Film minors must complete COR-2XX and complete 36 credits.

courses.title: Advanced Cinematography
courses.description: Advanced Cinematography offers students the  opportunity to deepen their aesthetic study and  practice of the craft through the employment of  atmospheric lighting, integration of camera and  production design, and complex camera movements.   The course covers the importance of constructive  collaboration and effective crew management. Over  the course of the semester, students will produce  short works in both field and studio  environments, as well as study examples of  cinematography at work in the industry and  elsewhere.
courses.subject: Filmmaking
courses.prereq: FLM-225 or permission of the Program Director

courses.title: Video Comp & Special Effects
courses.description: This course introduces students to special effects  and compositing. Through classroom instruction  and project-based work, students will learn and  gain command of industry standard software.  By  the end of the semester, students will have the  ability to skillfully demonstrate the use of  effects, animation, keying, motion graphics, and  color correction.
courses.subject: Filmmaking

courses.title: Adv Topics in Game Networking
courses.description: Students will learn modern, robust game networking techniques that are standard throughout the games industry. They will explore methods of enhancing user experience and analyzing performance trade-offs beyond what is covered in GPR-430.
courses.subject: Game Programming

courses.title: College Capstone:Filmmaking
courses.description: The college capstone is an opportunity for students to pursue a self-directed experience in their professional program that intentionally integrates their liberal learning in the Core curriculum with their program learning.  In addition to the substantive professional-based hands-on project in this class, the capstone will include a professional ethics component and a self-evaluation/self-reflection component.
courses.subject: College Capstone
courses.prereq: Must complete COR-310, COR-320, and two sections of COR-330 All Game majors (EGPR.BS, GDES.BS, GART.BS must also complete EGD-320 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Screenwriting III
courses.description: Students will complete their first draft of a  feature film based on a detailed outline produced  in Screenwriting II.  Through readings and scene  dissections, students will delve into dialogue,  scene construction, description, action, and the  use of imagery.  Pathways for professional  screenwriters will be explored, including agents,  managers, festivals, and studios.  Students will  produce a 90 - 120 page script by the end of the  semester.
courses.subject: Filmmaking

courses.title: Image Technology
courses.description: Students are introduced to the basic concepts of digital image-making through projects that balance the learning of creative development, technique, and design tools as they pertain to the Graphic Design field.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Design Solutions
courses.description: Here is your opportunity to bring your communication ideas to life. You will learn how to plan, design, typeset, produce artwork, proof, and manage production for brochures, posters, and other communication collateral materials. You will learn the basic language of design and the overall production process-all to help you produce these projects yourself or work with design and production professionals to produce complex projects. Some basic art supplies will be required.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Form in Motion
courses.description: Form in Motion introduces the principles of motion graphic design through applied practice. The focus will be on the relationship between typographic principles and animation fundamentals. Students synthesize the language of motion with elements of narrative structure to realize kinetic solutions. In addition to exploring systems and the synthesis of text and image, the course also provides knowledge and skills in creative ideation in motion.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Fundamentals of Acting
courses.description: Provides students with an understanding of acting techniques, with emphasis on movement, discipline, breathing and concentration. They will investigate the creation of character in preparation for acting in the classroom.
courses.subject: Theater

courses.title: Japanese I
courses.description: Students learn to use Japanese language at a level that lets them function in simple situations encountered in travel and on business trips. Four skill areas will be taught with equal emphasis: listening, speaking, reading and writing.
courses.subject: Language

courses.title: Japanese II
courses.description: Compared to introductory Japanese, this second course emphasizes an increase in students' active language skills (generating responses, initiating questions, initiating verbal exchanges. Students will be made aware of subtle cues for language as this course explores social situations, business situations and an awareness of appropriate degrees of formality. At the same time, Japanese II continues to give students practice in the foundation skills acquired in Japanese I and in particular the four skill areas of listening, speaking, reading and writing.
courses.subject: Language
courses.prereq: LAN-140 or permission from the Dean.

courses.title: Collab. Project-Based: EMC
courses.description: This course brings together students from different majors to work on multidisciplinary team-based projects associated with community partners. The course emphasizes collaboration, communication, and problem-solving skills essential for success in the modern workforce. Students will learn how to work in diverse teams, identify and analyze complex problems, and develop innovative solutions that meet the needs of clients. Projects will be designed in partnership with external partners or communities and may focus on topics such as (but not limited to) product design, marketing strategy, social impact, creative works, or sustainability. Through hands-on project work and reflective practice, students will gain practical experience in project management, leadership, and effective teamwork across disciplinary boundaries. By the end of the course, students will have completed at least one professional-level project they can showcase to potential employers.
courses.subject: Champlain College Exp.

courses.title: Intermediate Typography
courses.description: Building upon the history and basic use of letterforms, students will now extend their typographic practice by focusing on font usage, paragraph and page structure and grid development. Working with more complex issues of hierarchy, contrast, scale, rhythm, and spatial relationships in typographic projects that focus on sequential designs, such as the pages of a book. Historical context and current technologies will also be discussed.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Intro to 3D Motion Graphics
courses.description: Develop 3D skills for motion design. Obtain a solid grounding in basic elements and principles of design in 3D digital graphics by creating product graphics, signage systems, 3D illustrations, type animation and infographics.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom
courses.prereq: Complete either GDV-203, FLM-330, or GAA-105

courses.title: Graphic Production
courses.description: Professional graphic design practice requires skills and knowledge both in producing digital artwork and in supervising the print production process. This course introduces the requirements of digital artwork, pixel, vector, and page layout, in preparation for the offset printing press, and the protocol a designer must follow to execute the production process accurately and efficiently. This information is of vital importance to the junior designer because in their first job they will be expected to work on production-ready digital artwork, and participate in the job management process.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Projects in Graphic Design II
courses.description: Your learning and preparation through projects couched within specific lessons now transform into a truly personal graphic design practice as you engage various self-directed projects?from logos and stationery, to publications, to packages, to architectural signs and trade show displays. This course guides you through the conceptualization, design, and production to produce a body of work ready for presentation in your professional portfolio. (Consult with your advisor to choose the section most appropriate to your elective track.) Basic art supplies will be required.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom
courses.prereq: VCDS majors only. Must complete 84 credits before taking this course.

courses.title: Portfolio Studio
courses.description: This course will guide you through the process of finalizing, organizing and assembling your graphic design projects into an engaging portfolio that represents you as a designer, as a thinker, and as a person. Your portfolio will respond to your emphasis, from traditional book forms to motion and web design. Purchase of portfolio materials will be necessary, and students will need basic art supplies.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Creative Writing 1
courses.description: This course introduces students to the work of writing creatively, encouraging them to become more attentive readers, as preparation for their own growth as writers. We'll survey a range of literary texts, developing a deeper understanding of how creative genres work, what parameters structure them, and how they might be deployed in our own writing. Students will experiment within their own fiction, poetry, and nonfiction writing. The bedrock of our class will be peer review, so students can read and learn from each others' work.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Creative Writing 1
courses.description: This course introduces students to the work of writing creatively, encouraging them to become more attentive readers, as preparation for their own growth as writers. We'll survey a range of literary texts, developing a deeper understanding of how creative genres work, what parameters structure them, and how they might be deployed in our own writing. Students will experiment within their own fiction, poetry, and nonfiction writing. The bedrock of our class will be peer review, so students can read and learn from each others' work.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Fundamentals of Journalism
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic skills of reporting with hands-on experience in gathering news,interviewing, researching, and investigating. Students draft, edit and finalize news stories, profiles, features,news-features, reviews, and commentaries. Peer reviews and writing workshops will improve students' abilities to self-edit. Analytical discussion of current news is a central element of the course. Students also examine the contemporary news/media environment, corporate ownership of news organizations, and the central function that a free press plays in American democracy.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Creative Writing 2
courses.description: This course will further explore techniques used by poets and fiction writers.  Students will not only continue to analyze published works, produce portfolios of original work, and participate in the workshop process, but they will also be expected to submit their own writing for regional and national publication, as well as perform original poems/stories at a public reading.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Writing for the Workplace
courses.description: This course introduces students to the fundamental elements of professional writing (clear, concise, and targeted) that are common among seven forms of workplace?communication: email correspondence, cover letters, resumes, proposals, long formal reports, oral communication, and team projects. Through peer reviews and writing workshops, students develop the ability to write and edit text that precisely targets its audience. This course emphasizes deepening and broadening students' writing, speaking, and thinking abilities in a non-lecture-based, hands-on discussion-centered classroom.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Dev Editing & Publishing
courses.description: What does an editor's job involve? This course looks at the role of book editor, from acquiring a manuscript, working with authors to develop voice and make substantial changes, collaborating with design and production on jacket and interior design, and presenting to sales and marketing. Students will learn how book editing skills compare/contrast with other types of editing, including print and online, working with different genres and hearing from industry professionals. Collaborative workshops, peer editing, and peer review.
courses.subject: Writing

courses.title: Fiction Workshop 2
courses.description: This course is an intensive exploration of fiction writing. Presented as a seminar and writing workshop, the class reads and discusses short stories, novels, and essays on the art and craft of fiction writing. Writing three short stories (or the equivalent in chapters of a novel/novella) leads students to integrate theory and practice as they produce work informed by a detailed understanding of such common fictional elements as character, plot, setting, and conflict as well as more advanced concepts that foster finely wrought creative work. Students submit at least one original work for publication.
courses.subject: Writing
courses.prereq: WRT-226 or permission of Program Director.

courses.title: Intro to Brd Wrtng
courses.description: This course teaches the writing styles needed by journalists and media professionals. It stresses Associated Press style and the various types of story structures for radio, TV and web-based platforms. Students will apply their skills to creating content for audio and video mediums and will focus on news and feature writing formats.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod

courses.title: Audio Production
courses.description: This hands-on production course introduces audio techniques, covering the basics of writing, producing, and engineering productions for audio production. Students write, produce and perform a variety of programs including news, interviews, commercials, dramas and documentaries. Besides traditional analog recording techniques, students gain a solid understanding of digital audio recording and editing techniques for persuasion, information and entertainment.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod

courses.title: Radio Production I
courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic operation of a radio station.  Students will learn to produce audio content, sound board operation, creation of station promotions and IDs; the basics of interviewing and audience research; and the differences between broadcast and internet platforms for radio. Students will work closely with the college radio station, the Wave, in all assignments.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod

courses.title: Production of Social Media
courses.description: This content and hands on production class examines and creates audio and video for web cast, podcasts, and social media venues. Students will script, capture, edit, enhance and host audio and video projects for specific audiences.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod

courses.title: Show Producing II
courses.description: This course builds on the producing skills learned in BRD 250. Students will operate in producer roles such as line producer, segment producer, show producer and public affairs producer by creating programs for the audio and video mediums. Students will produce broadcast quality programming for commercial and noncommercial formats, develop proposals, conduct research, write scripts, and produce studio and field-based programming.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod
courses.prereq: Complete BRD-250 or receive permission from the Program Director

courses.title: Cult Imp of Tv
courses.description: This course offers a survey of modern media history through the study of the social and cultural impact of television series from the 1950's to the present.  Students explore the portrayal of life on television, the motives of the evolving broadcast industry and how modern culture is reflected in and shaped by programming.
courses.subject: Broadcast Media Prod
courses.prereq: Complete 60 credits; Open to juniors and seniors or permission of instructor.  Open to all majors.

courses.title: Broadcast Media Capstone
courses.description: The college capstone is an opportunity for students to pursue a self-directed experience in their professional program that intentionally integrates their liberal learning in the Core curriculum with their program learning.  In addition to the substantive professional-based hands-on project in this class, the capstone will include a professional ethics component and a self-evaluation/self-reflection component.
courses.subject: College Capstone
courses.prereq: Must complete COR-310, COR-320, and two sections of COR-330 All Game majors (EGPR.BS, GDES.BS, GART.BS must also complete EGD-320 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Capstone: Writing & Publishing
courses.description: The college capstone is an opportunity for students to pursue a self-directed experience in their professional program that intentionally integrates their liberal learning in the Core curriculum with their program learning.  In addition to the substantive professional-based hands-on project in this class, the capstone will include a professional ethics component and a self-evaluation/self-reflection component.
courses.subject: College Capstone
courses.prereq: Must complete COR-310, COR-320, and two sections of COR-330 All Game majors (EGPR.BS, GDES.BS, GART.BS must also complete EGD-320 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Transmedia Storytelling
courses.description: Transmedia storytelling is conceived in two ways: splintering-where a single story is split into pieces, and extension-where a single story/story world stretches in different directions via various media formats and platforms. Built around investigating both types, students assess works that showcase splintering/extension and through producing their own stories. They gain exposure to media theory and criticism that targets transmedia narrative, experiment with transmedia storytelling software and content platforms, and practice writing and designing content for a variety of media formats.
courses.subject: Writing
courses.prereq: WRT-120 AND EITHER WRT 220 OR WRT 226 OR GMD 230

courses.title: ITS Internship I
courses.description: Students in ITS obtain earn 2 academic credits for  successfully completing approximately 90 hours of  a technology related internship at an internship  site. Students will apply skills and aptitudes  developed in the classroom and engage in hands-on  work in a professional setting under the  direction of an on-site supervisor.
courses.subject: Info. Tech. & Sciences

courses.title: Victimology
courses.description: Victimology, the study of victims of crime, is a subdiscipline of criminology with contributions from psychology, social work, economics, law, cybersecurity, and other fields. This course examines the causes, consequences, and responses to crime victims. It begins by introducing the concept of victimology and its historical development. Students will explore various types of victimization, including interpersonal violence, hate crimes, property crimes, and cybercrimes. They will also examine victimization's physical, psychological, social, and financial impact on individuals, families, and society.
courses.subject: Criminal Justice

courses.title: Intro to Digital Humanities
courses.description: Students gain a foundational understanding of the field of Digital Humanities by asking important questions, and experimenting with how to address those questions by drawing on different knowledge domains ranging from science and technology to philosophy, the arts, and communication. Students will apply critical perspectives from the humanities and social sciences with hands-on exploration of digital methods such as augmented reality, story mapping, and text scraping to name only a few possibilities.
courses.subject: Digital Humanities

courses.title: Game Snd Des II
courses.description: Students will create music and special effects for game levels, menus and game environments.  Working in groups, students will develop sound design concepts, create documentation, prepare and load sound and special effects into a game engine and conduct quality assurance testing. The course requires students to provide constructive criticism to individual and group work. This course is required of all Game Sound Design majors.
courses.subject: Game Sound Design

courses.title: Dublin Literary Experience
courses.description: Digital methods are widely used forms of inquiry that employ technological tools to interrogate research questions important to the humanities and sciences (including the social sciences). Some examples include digital archiving, data mining, and story mapping. In this course, we will use one or more digital methods or tools to research a topic, theme or question that varies by section, with the express purpose of critiquing and reflecting on its application. This includes an examination of the values, flaws, and impacts of the methods or tools we are using, paying particular attention to their ethical implications and power dynamics. For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-three
courses.subject: Core
courses.prereq: Take COR-101, COR-102, COR-103, COR-104, COR-201, COR-202, COR-203, COR-204

courses.title: Intro. Interactive Narrative
courses.description: What exactly is interactive narrative? You'll find out by playing some of the best games in the narrative canon, but you'll also have a chance to experience other forms of interactive story, from museum exhibits to escape rooms. Then You'll also learn the basics of creating your own interactive story. Learn about what narrative professionals do during visits by industry professionals.  We'll also cover various forms of interactive story worldwide, from sea shanties to shamanism to Santa Claus.
courses.subject: Interactive Narrative

courses.title: Interactive Narrative I
courses.description: Prepare for professional work in interactive narrative in this rigorous but fun class, where you'll completedo actual on-the-job projectsassignments to hone your skills and get your creativity flowing. We'll analyze important games and interactive works, learn industry tools and create works to build your narrative portfolio.
courses.subject: Interactive Narrative

courses.title: Interactive Narrative II
courses.description: Interactive Narrative II builds on the concepts, tools and skills from Interactive I. In this course you'll create narrative structures beyond simple branching, as you gain a deeper understanding of narrative design theory. You'll hone your player-facing writing skills to write professional-quality dialogue and text. Projects in this class will challenge you to complete real-world assignments on time and to specifications. You'll gain proficiency with industry-standard tools and bring your analysis, critique and revision skills to a professional level. This course provides a strong foundation for the Advanced Seminar and eventual work in the field.
courses.subject: Interactive Narrative

courses.title: Intro. to Irish Life & Culture
courses.description: By learning from the past, we can make sense of the present and prepare for the future. In this course, we will learn how the 21st century has been and continues to be shaped by past social practices, ethical frameworks, power relations, and discourses. COR 303 is a course about how we know what we know about the past, and the ways different narratives about the past shape the present. Making connections between past and present will help us better understand how to live and make decisions in a globalized world defined by constant change.
courses.subject: Core
courses.prereq: Take COR-101, COR-102, COR-103, COR-104, COR-201, COR-202, COR-203, COR-204

courses.title: Intro to 2D Digital Art
courses.description: Introduces essential art and design topics including the elements of design, color theory, and composition. These principles are introduced through the creation of 2D digital art using industry standard software.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation or Creative Media students only or by permission of Game Art Program Director

courses.title: Drawing for Realism I
courses.description: Learn to draw the human figure through the study of form, volume, structure and anatomy in order to clearly visualize position and proportion of anatomical landmarks. Students will use traditional drawing techniques to understand the concepts of proportion, foreshortening, lighting and composition to realistically render the human form.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation and Creative Media students only or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro 3D Modeling & Texturing
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the foundation principles of 3D modeling and texturing for games. Students will learn to create optimized and aesthetically successful textured 3D models that work within the constraints of graphics production for real-time 3D game engines.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design, Game Programming, Creative Media students only or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro 3D Modeling & Texturing
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the foundation principles of 3D modeling and texturing for games. Students will learn to create optimized and aesthetically successful textured 3D models that work within the constraints of graphics production for real-time 3D game engines.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design, Game Programming, Creative Media students only or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro 3D Modeling & Texturing
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the foundation principles of 3D modeling and texturing for games. Students will learn to create optimized and aesthetically successful textured 3D models that work within the constraints of graphics production for real-time 3D game engines.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design, Game Programming, Creative Media students only or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro to Animation
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of animation and the aesthetics of motion. Students will learn to apply these principles to create beginner level 2D and 3D animations.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design or Creative Media students or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro to Animation
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of animation and the aesthetics of motion. Students will learn to apply these principles to create beginner level 2D and 3D animations.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design or Creative Media students or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Intro to Animation
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the fundamental principles of animation and the aesthetics of motion. Students will learn to apply these principles to create beginner level 2D and 3D animations.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Game Art, Animation, Game Design or Creative Media students or by permission of Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: 3D Modeling
courses.description: Building on the fundamental skills developed in Introduction to 3D Modeling & Texturing, students create detailed 3D models that are optimized for use in real-time game engines. Focus will be on refining high poly to low poly baking techniques, texture creation workflow, and in-engine material and lighting techniques.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Take GAA-135, grade C or higher.

courses.title: Concept Painting, Foundations
courses.description: To harness the power of the visual, the successful concept artist must couple a balanced composition of light, form, space, and axes of action with narrative. In this course you will learn to tell the engaging stories of your imagination by exercising the fundamentals of digital painting.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation

courses.title: Concept Painting, Foundations
courses.description: To harness the power of the visual, the successful concept artist must couple a balanced composition of light, form, space, and axes of action with narrative. In this course you will learn to tell the engaging stories of your imagination by exercising the fundamentals of digital painting.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation

courses.title: Concept Painting, Foundations
courses.description: To harness the power of the visual, the successful concept artist must couple a balanced composition of light, form, space, and axes of action with narrative. In this course you will learn to tell the engaging stories of your imagination by exercising the fundamentals of digital painting.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation

courses.title: 3D Modeling II
courses.description: 3D Modeling II builds on the subjects covered in 3D Modeling I with a focus on modeling organic forms using digital sculpting software and techniques. Although the course focuses on organic forms, digital sculpting technology and related workflows are prevalent in the modeling of solid surface objects as well. We will also focus on using 3D painting, mesh topology and hi-poly to low-poly baking.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Complete GAA-235 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: 3D Modeling II
courses.description: 3D Modeling II builds on the subjects covered in 3D Modeling I with a focus on modeling organic forms using digital sculpting software and techniques. Although the course focuses on organic forms, digital sculpting technology and related workflows are prevalent in the modeling of solid surface objects as well. We will also focus on using 3D painting, mesh topology and hi-poly to low-poly baking.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Complete GAA-235 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: 3D Animation I
courses.description: This course focuses on the aesthetics of motion with emphasis on the principles of traditional animation. Students begin with the basics of putting 3D models in motion and work through the tools, techniques, and principles required to animate fully articulated characters using skeletal deformation and control rigs. This course emphasizes the realization of the principles of animation through group critique.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Complete GAA-175 with a minimum grade of C.

courses.title: Animation Studio I
courses.description: In Animation Studio I, students work together in small teams to conceptualize, plan and create an animated short film. While working collaboratively, students will experience the professional roles associated with the various stages of the production process. In the early stages of pre-production, each team will decide whether to work in 2D or 3D and will assess the needs of the production accordingly.
courses.subject: Animation

courses.title: 3D Lighting & Rendering
courses.description: Lighting a 3D scene involves more than setting parameters to simulate real world lighting. Lighting should be designed to achieve visual goals, set the mood for the scene and guide the viewer's attention. In this course students will learn the theory and practice of lighting 3D scenes for pre-rendered animation.
courses.subject: Animation

courses.title: Procedural 3D Modeling
courses.description: Students will learn to apply procedural 3D modeling techniques to develop 3D assets with creator-defined adjustable parameters, allowing for quick iteration and the creation of a variety of models from one procedural node network.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: Take GAA-135 grade C or higher.

courses.title: Technical Art
courses.description: Technical Art brings together programming and art, relying extensively on an artist's knowledge of workflow, tools and art-production practices in the area of 3d graphics production. By combining this knowledge with a foundation in programming, students write tools and develop art pipelines to be used personally by other artists, and production teams. This course requires no previous knowledge of programming and covers the creation of custom tools and associated user-faces in a 3d software environment.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 60 Credits and GAA-235, minimum grade C.

courses.title: Adv Seminar: Art & Animation
courses.description: The Advanced Seminar in Game Art & Animation course is designed as a supplement to the foundation classes in Game Art & Animation, allowing students to concentrate on creating marketable portfolio pieces of their own determination. Students will create a detailed semester-long plan, including specific milestones and deliverables, and work throughout the semester with an instructor on creating dynamic work for their portfolio.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 60 credits completed and approval of the Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Adv Seminar: Art & Animation
courses.description: The Advanced Seminar in Game Art & Animation course is designed as a supplement to the foundation classes in Game Art & Animation, allowing students to concentrate on creating marketable portfolio pieces of their own determination. Students will create a detailed semester-long plan, including specific milestones and deliverables, and work throughout the semester with an instructor on creating dynamic work for their portfolio.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 60 credits completed and approval of the Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Adv Seminar: Art & Animation
courses.description: The Advanced Seminar in Game Art & Animation course is designed as a supplement to the foundation classes in Game Art & Animation, allowing students to concentrate on creating marketable portfolio pieces of their own determination. Students will create a detailed semester-long plan, including specific milestones and deliverables, and work throughout the semester with an instructor on creating dynamic work for their portfolio.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 60 credits completed and approval of the Game Art Program Director.

courses.title: Sr Portfolio: Game Art
courses.description: The culmination of your art degree is your portfolio. As a game artist this includes a demo-reel, portfolio website, print materials and some final preparations for transitioning into the job market. In Senior Portfolio you will finalize your portfolio work and compile your visual portfolio into a dynamic and marketable combination of materials. To successfully complete the course you are required to have an approved body of work.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 90 credits completed, Game Art students only.

courses.title: Sr Portfolio: Game Art
courses.description: The culmination of your art degree is your portfolio. As a game artist this includes a demo-reel, portfolio website, print materials and some final preparations for transitioning into the job market. In Senior Portfolio you will finalize your portfolio work and compile your visual portfolio into a dynamic and marketable combination of materials. To successfully complete the course you are required to have an approved body of work.
courses.subject: Game Art & Animation
courses.prereq: 90 credits completed, Game Art students only.

courses.title: Visual Comm. for Game Design
courses.description: Communication is at the center of success for a Game Designer. Visual Communication for Game Designers takes an integrated approach exploring technology, visual design aesthetics and principles, and visual design communication forms most often used by game designers to successfully communicate their ideas to their teams and build and test good user interaction models.
courses.subject: Game Design

courses.title: Visual Comm. for Game Design

courses.subject: Game Design

courses.title: Introduction to Game Design
courses.description: What's the difference between an FPS and an RPG? Are discovery and exploration important in every style of game, or can they detract from a cool game concept? We answer these questions by examining genres in games and analyzing some of the gameplay styles associated with them. Then, once we've discovered strengths and  weaknesses inherent to particular game styles, we'll develop skills necessary to formulate and evauluate our own original gameplay ideas.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design, CREM or Game Production Management majors only, or permission of Game Design Program Director.

courses.title: Creativity and Play
courses.description: In this course, students will learn how to exercise, practice and cultivate creativity. Students will learn the value of the creative process, the role of creativity in play and culture and how to develop their ideas through iterative processes. Students will employ a variety of creative tools and techniques to develop a lasting creative practice.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design and CREM majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director.

courses.title: Game Technology I
courses.description: Game designers need an essential skill set that allows them to realize their concepts through working prototypes. In Game Technology I students learn how to develop and manipulate game mechanics and environments through visual and traditional scripting tools. This class is the first in a series that supports skills needed for level editing and design, prototyping, and working in game engines.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: CSI-140 or CSI-160 and Game Design, CREM or Game Art majors only, or permission of Game Design Program Director.

courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: CSI-140 or CSI-160 and Game Design, CREM or Game Art majors only, or permission of Game Design Program Director.

courses.title: Level Design
courses.description: A level designer controls moment by moment what a player sees, hears and feels during the game experience. Following the broader direction of the game designer, the level designer creates the setting and crafts the challenges for each individual level. The style and content of individual game levels must establish the right mood, support the anticipated functionality, advance the storyline, and satisfy the idiosyncratic requirements of the players. Building on the design foundation of Conceptual Design, this course teaches students how to successfully design, draft, document, and implement successful game levels.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-200 and GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Level Design
courses.description: A level designer controls moment by moment what a player sees, hears and feels during the game experience. Following the broader direction of the game designer, the level designer creates the setting and crafts the challenges for each individual level. courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-200 and GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Game Technology II
courses.description: Acquire the integration skills needed to successfully build a 3D game.  In Game Engine I we explore both the technical construction and practical design of games in a 3D game engine. The technical skills required to use the game engine software are combined with knowing how and when to use spaces in a level, construct an interface, establish moods, and direct a player's attention through sound effects, lighting, camera angles, and text to create a complete working game.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-200 with a C or better.

courses.title: Game Sys. & Experience Design
courses.description: At the core of every game experience are the systems that generate that experience. In this advanced game design course, we will examine a full spectrum of game experiences and deconstruct their systems. We will look at the many facets of creating a player-centric game experience from the cultural significance of games and play to conceptualizing and proving concepts for a broad range of game media target markets and purposes.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Game Sys. & Experience Design
courses.description: At the core of every game experience are the systems that generate that experience. In this advanced game design course, we will examine a full spectrum of game experiences and deconstruct their systems. We will look at the many facets of creating a player-centric game experience from the cultural significance of games and play to conceptualizing and proving concepts for a broad range of game media target markets and purposes.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Level Design II
courses.description: The goal of the successful level designer is to create compelling experiences for the player. Level Design II builds off the foundational conceptual and technical knowledge established in Level Design I. Students in this course explore advanced topics of level design while building and polishing game level environments. Some topics include creating and balancing mechanics, systems and gameplay, developing engaging play environments, narrative and content development, lighting and special effects, and engine scripting and optimization.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of Game Design Program Director and complete GMD-240 with a C or better.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar: Game Design
courses.description: Advanced Seminars vary in topic and are designed to provide the advanced student with time for personal development of their portfolio in a specific area of Game Design. Examples of projects include: Designing and documenting an original game concept. Designing, documenting, and constructing a series of level mods. Designing and constructing a mobile game. Designing and constructing and alternative controller. Students propose and create a production schedule for their semester projects, have multiple critiques through the semester and present portfolio quality work at completion of the course. See current semester course offerings for available topics.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of the Game Design Program Director.  Complete GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar Int Narrative
courses.description: Advanced Seminars vary in topic and are designed to provide the advanced student with time for personal development of their portfolio in a specific area of Game Design. Examples of projects include: Designing and documenting an original game concept. Designing, documenting, and constructing a series of level mods. Designing and constructing a mobile game. Designing and constructing and alternative controller. Students propose and create a production schedule for their semester projects, have multiple critiques through the semester and present portfolio quality work at completion of the course. See current semester course offerings for available topics.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: Game Design majors only or permission of the Game Design Program Director.  Complete GMD-210 with a C or better.

courses.title: Senior Portfolio: Game Design
courses.description: Looking to land a job as a game designer? In today's fast changing industry, you'll need to demonstrate top-notch skills, get attention, and stand out from the crowd. This class allows you to define, refine, and develop an individual body of work that will capture the attention of hiring managers. Emphasis is on presentation, editing, and organization of a personal portfolio, under the guidance of faculty to ensure a professional product.
courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: 90 credits completed, GDES.BS students only, or by permission of the CCM Division Dean.

courses.title: Senior Portfolio: Game Design
courses.description: Looking to land a job as a game designer? In today's fast changing industry, you'll need to demonstrate top-notch skills, get attention, and stand out from the crowd. Emphasis is on presentation, editing, and organization of a personal portfolio, under the guidance of faculty to ensure a professional product.

courses.prereq: 90 credits completed, GDES.BS students only, or by permission of the CCM Division Dean.

courses.description: Looking to land a job as a game designer? In today's fast changing industry, you'll need to demonstrate top-notch skills, get attention, and stand out from the crowd. courses.subject: Game Design
courses.prereq: 90 credits completed, GDES.BS students only, or by permission of the CCM Division Dean.

courses.title: Intro to Game Engines for Sou
courses.description: This introductory course focuses on navigating and utilizing industry-standard game engines. Students will learn language and terminology common to game development environments, gain familiarity with navigating a game engine interface, understand the basics of implementing assets in-engine, implement basic audio in-engine, and be introduced to C# and Blueprints programming concepts.
courses.subject: Game Sound Design

courses.title: Game Snd Des II
courses.description: Students will create music and special effects for game levels, menus and game environments.  Working in groups, students will develop sound design concepts, create documentation, prepare and load sound and special effects into a game engine and conduct quality assurance testing. The course requires students to provide constructive criticism to individual and group work. This course is required of all Game Sound Design majors.
courses.subject: Game Sound Design

courses.title: Sound Studio Production
courses.description: The recording and mixing of sound requires numerous aesthetic decisions that are technically realized. This hands-on class introduces students to the use of the Sound Studio for recording, mixing, and mastering audio. Through lectures and in-studio practice, students gain a comprehensive understanding and working knowledge of the professional recording environment. There will be recording and mixing projects as well technical evaluations, all done in the CCM Sound Studio.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts
courses.prereq: Must have approval from the Dean or designee

courses.title: Champ 101
courses.description: Champ 101 meets for the first 10 weeks of the semester, and attendance is required through the InSight Program. A Faculty/Staff Facilitator and a Peer Facilitator work together with a cohort of First Year and Transfer students, engaging in workshops focused on building community with peers and supporting the academic, social, and personal transition to Champlain. There is no out-of-classroom work and the program is non-credit bearing.
courses.subject: Champ FYE

courses.title: Reading & Writing: Spec Topics
courses.description: Reading & Writing: Special Topics is a rotating subject course that offers students the opportunity to read and write deeply across a broad spectrum of artistic, cultural and historic literature in specific genres to be as representative as possible of the world literature canon. Genres covered in each course will vary based on the changing market and student interests.
courses.subject: Writing
courses.prereq: WRT-120 AND either WRT 220 OR WRT 226 OR WRT 237. Course may be taken up to 3 times for credit.

courses.title: ITS Internship II
courses.description: Students in ITS obtain earn 2 academic credits for  successfully completing approximately 90 hours of  a technology related internship at an internship  site. Students will apply skills and aptitudes  developed in the classroom and engage in hands-on  work in a professional setting under the  direction of an on-site supervisor.
courses.subject: Info. Tech. & Sciences

courses.title: Cybersecurity Fundamentals
courses.description: In this course, students will learn the foundational concepts of cybersecurity. The course will cover system and data security principles. Students will explore the organizational, societal, and global implications of cybersecurity with a focus on ethics, risk management, and adversarial analysis.
courses.subject: Information Security

courses.title: Sound Studio Production
courses.description: The recording and mixing of sound requires numerous aesthetic decisions that are technically realized. This hands-on class introduces students to the use of the Sound Studio for recording, mixing, and mastering audio. Through lectures and in-studio practice, students gain a comprehensive understanding and working knowledge of the professional recording environment. There will be recording and mixing projects as well technical evaluations, all done in the CCM Sound Studio.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts
courses.prereq: Must have approval from the Dean or designee

courses.title: Fundamentals of Digital Music
courses.description: This course will teach students the basics of music, and how to create music on the computer. Topics include rhythm, phrasing, harmony, melody, and song construction. This is an exciting opportunity, given the virtually unlimited power of today?s Digital Audio Workstations. Music can be assembled from pre-composed elements, played live into the computer, written as notes on an electronic score, or keyed in using a midi piano keyboard. Students will use these digital tools to capture their ideas or inspiration and turn them into music. Several projects will be required, in various styles, for a number of different purposes.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts

courses.title: History of Musical Innovation
courses.description: Provides a historical context for the music of our age, including the study of medieval through contemporary musical styles of Europe and the U.S. Particular attention will be given to innovations that transformed Western musical thought and expression through the ages. Students will develop listening skills and gain an understanding of the roots, influences and cross-cultural impacts of music of their own time and place through experience with music listening, readings, discussion and comparative analysis.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts

courses.title: Synthesis and Sound Design
courses.description: After a brief history of the development of electronic synthesis, students will delve into creating sounds using current industry standard synthesizers. Types of synthesis will include virtual analog, frequency modulation and physical modeling. Digital audio workstations will be used to record and organize the sounds. The vast array of electronic effects in Logic will also be explored. Students will gain a functional knowledge of not only synthesis, but also powerful electronic effect and sequencing options.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts

courses.title: Adv. Projects in Sonic Arts
courses.description: Offers the opportunity to do advanced scoring and sound design work. Students will propose a substantial project (such as scoring a film, or building sound for game levels), then take the project from conception to final recording, including composition, sound design, orchestration, recording, signal processing, mixing and mastering. Some exceptional projects may be selected for live recording sessions in a professional studio. Students will create portfolio pieces that go beyond technical proficiency, honing their work to generate emotional impact.
courses.subject: Sonic Arts
courses.prereq: SON-120 and one of the following: SON-340, SON-350, BRD-330. Or by permission of Dean.

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: DDL Capstone III
courses.description: A senior-level seminar during which students implement and verify a technical capstone project specific to their major discipline that they have researched and designed under the supervision of their principal faculty member.  Completed projects will be fully documented and presented in writing and orally to appropriate audiences.
courses.subject: College Capstone
courses.prereq: Complete CCC-410ITS with a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Advanced Seminar - Game Dev
courses.description: Explore cutting-edge concepts in the game industry in the Advanced Seminar in Game Development. Designed for all students in the Game Studio at Champlain College, this interdisciplinary, project-based, dynamic course covers diverse special topics each semester with a focus on industry trends, skills and knowledge needed to stay at the forefront of the ever-evolving gaming industry. Can be taken up to three times for credit.
courses.subject: Electronic Game Develop
courses.prereq: 60 credits. Students must be enrolled in one of the following programs: Game Business and Publishing, Game Art, Game Design, Game Production Management, Game Programming, Game Sound Design, or Interactive Narrative, or by permission of the Dean or designee.

courses.title: Intro to Typography
courses.description: An understanding of typography is fundamental to your professional graphic design practice. Through an historical overview of the evolution of letterforms, you will understand the visual evolution of the Latin alphabet as a result of social, cultural, and technical influences. You will gain an understanding of the nuances of type design and develop proficiency in speaking the language of type specification, in creating beautiful designs using letterforms and blocks of text, and in setting typography digitally.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: Global Studies Senior Seminar
courses.description: Allows seniors in the Global Studies minor to deepen their understanding of global relationships, institutions, and differences, and to explore their own path towards a globalized personal and professional life. Students write a biography of a global citizen, study an international institution that impacts their future profession, and use social theory as a tool for understanding identity, power, and resistance on the world stage. Offered only during fall semesters.
courses.subject: Core
courses.prereq: Permission of the Assistant Dean of Global Engagement. Intended for senior students in the Global Studies Minor.

courses.title: Project Design I
courses.description: This course provides a project design space for students enrolled in the Degree Design Lab Program to develop and explore a sustained interdisciplinary question through a collaborative problem or project.  While the collective project may be pre-determined, students will be challenged to identify how their multiple professional foci OR other compelling passions might contribute. Faculty will help students to identify the project, facilitate implementation, ensure appropriate breadth and depth of subject matter, and encourage awareness of how the experience can be used to build and demonstrate competency. Students will develop their own questions and determine their own research path for the liberal learning that will help them achieve their goals.  Students will actively share ideas, engage in ongoing discussions, provide feedback, and refine work accordingly. This course is designed with an eye towards increasing independence and sophistication, and will allow students at different points in their process and with different perspectives to contribute to each other's work.
courses.subject: Degree Design Lab

courses.title: Project Design II
courses.description: This project sandbox space is for DDL students to explore an interdisciplinary question, problem or project.  Students can either identify a project that connects their multiple professional foci OR one that incorporates other passions and interests.  With faculty mentorship, students will develop their question and determine their research path.  This course is designed with an eye towards increasing independence and sophistication, and allows students at different points in their process with different perspectives to contribute to each other's work. Students may enroll more than once.
courses.subject: Degree Design Lab
courses.prereq: Take DDL-180 and DDL-190. Take DDL-280

courses.title: Design Systems
courses.description: Students will employ effective visual communication strategies and adopt a user-centered methodology to craft aesthetically compelling designs that cross media. This course prepares students for the dynamic shifts in the design industry through the acquisition of a comprehensive skill set, spanning both traditional and emerging design platforms. Learning focuses on the integration of design elements within diverse systems and cultivates capabilities in critical thinking and problem-solving.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom
courses.prereq: Take 1 course: GDV-100 GDV-110 GAA-105 IXD-200

courses.title: Advanced Typography
courses.description: Having explored the history and basic use of letterforms, you can now delve deeper into various aspects of the written word, typography, and its relation to imagery. In this course you will approach design solutions using solely typographic form and together with images. From font usage, to paragraph and page structure, students explore how typographic form interacts with literary content, and how the current critical milieu influences typographic thinking. Specific technical and/or aesthetic considerations necessary in composing type for digital delivery are considered, and students will also try their hand at digital font design.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.

courses.description: Students will build a portfolio of work, and reflect on the learning developed through that work, to demonstrate proficiency in Analysis College competency.

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.

courses.title: Global Environmental Earth Sci
courses.description: Global Environmental Earth Science is a multi-disciplinary course in which students will explore a wide variety of topics including biodiversity, soil, water, forestry, climate change, alternative energy and others. This course is both timely and relevant to the society and world in which Champlain College students live. The scientific basis of environmental topics will be studied in order to more fully understand the current environmental issues of our times. Active inquiry and discussion of environmental issues will be complemented by fieldwork and hands-on experiments.
courses.subject: Science

courses.title: Modeling Non-Euclidean Geomet.
courses.description: After establishing an understanding of the axiomatic foundations across all geometries and the role of the Parallel Postulate in them, students will research and build virtual interactive models of Non-Euclidean Geometries.  Potential models include the Poincar? disk, Beltrami-Klein disk, Poincare half-plane, Klein disc.  With time permitting, students will also explore the geometry of quaternions and extensions of projective geometries.
courses.subject: Math

courses.title: FYI: Digital Humanities
courses.description: This course introduces you to interdisciplinary inquiry using applied, project-based, and/or experiential methods. Regardless of the specific course focus, you'll have opportunities for making and doing interdisciplinary knowledge creation through a variety of approaches and activities. You will collaborate with other students, iterate on ideas, and work to develop a project. For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-one

courses.title: Food Writing in Montreal
courses.description: Digital methods are widely used forms of inquiry that employ technological tools to interrogate research questions important to the humanities and sciences (including the social sciences). Some examples include digital archiving, data mining, and story mapping. In this course, we will use one or more digital methods or tools to research a topic, theme or question that varies by section, with the express purpose of critiquing and reflecting on its application. This includes an examination of the values, flaws, and impacts of the methods or tools we are using, paying particular attention to their ethical implications and power dynamics. For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-three

courses.title: Game Studio II
courses.description: In Game Studio II, students from all of the degrees of the Game Studio work together in large, multidisciplinary teams to rapidly conceptualize, pitch, plan and develop a 3D game. Students utilize the latest in game technology, while perfecting their collaborative, communication skills, and agile project management techniques.

courses.prereq: GDES.BS, GART.BS, GPRO.BS, GPMG.BS, GMSD.BS, GMBP.BS only. EGD-220, minimum grade of C. courses.title: Social Justice Intensive
courses.description: Students will meet together in an interdisciplinary, seminar-style setting to build a greater understanding of integrative thinking and learning and to add a focus within a social justice context.  Students will participate in an off-campus service learning project and critically examine the experience from the perspectives of social work, criminal justice, the law, environmental policy, education, psychology, and additionally consider their experiences in Core, and LEAD.
courses.subject: Education&Human Studies
courses.prereq: EHS 100 is a prerequisite for EHS 210, except for the following circumstances:  1) Student taking EHS 210 is a non-EHS student. OR  2) Student taking EHS 210 is a transfer student who came in as a sophomore or junior.

courses.title: Science Meaning Making
courses.description: Science holds an elevated place in society. The knowledge and meaning that science makes are seen as having a particular and special value. This course explores knowledge and meaning making in order to allow a thoughtful analysis of, and then engagement with, science as a way of knowing, and then engages with the methods and theories of the sciences themselves, to understand the analytical, creative, and generative possibilities of science.
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: IDP: [TOPIC/THEME]
courses.description: While each section of COR 202 addresses a different problem, issue, or topic, they all focus on interdisciplinary research. You will collect, analyze, and assess information from different disciplines in order to recognize patterns, contextualize arguments and synthesize ideas while collaborating on a project. Emphasis will be placed on helping you translate and apply what you learn about interdisciplinary research to other professional contexts.  For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-two
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: Culture Meaning Making
courses.description: Culture impacts everything we do, experience, and learn, but what is culture? Where does it come from, how does it form, and why does it have such a wide and deep impact on people's lives? This course explores culture as a system of meaning and meaning-making in order to allow for a more thoughtful analysis of, and then engagement with, cultural texts and media using different methodological approaches.

courses.title: Theory: Marxism and the Movies
courses.description: In this course, you will go in depth about a theoretical perspective that asks you to interrogate systems of power and power relationships. You will learn about the history of that perspective, including how it too was shaped by multiple contexts and compares with other viewpoints. You will use that perspective to analyze a specific topic, collection of texts, or cultural phenomena.  For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-two

courses.description: In this course, you will go in depth about a theoretical perspective that asks you to interrogate systems of power and power relationships. You will learn about the history of that perspective, including how it too was shaped by multiple contexts and compares with other viewpoints. You will use that perspective to analyze a specific topic, collection of texts, or cultural phenomena.  For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-two
courses.subject: Core

courses.title: Digital Methods
courses.description: Digital methods are widely used forms of inquiry that employ technological tools to interrogate research questions important to the humanities and sciences (including the social sciences). Some examples include digital archiving, data mining, and story mapping. In this course, we will use one or more digital methods or tools to research a topic, theme or question that varies by section, with the express purpose of critiquing and reflecting on its application. This includes an examination of the values, flaws, and impacts of the methods or tools we are using, paying particular attention to their ethical implications and power dynamics. For detailed descriptions of the individual sections of this course, cut and paste the following link into your browser: bit.ly/core-year-three

courses.title: Cultural Imm. Thru Can. Music
courses.description: By learning from the past, we can make sense of the present and prepare for the future. In this course, we will learn how the 21st century has been and continues to be shaped by past social practices, ethical frameworks, power relations, and discourses. COR 303 is a course about how we know what we know about the past, and the ways different narratives about the past shape the present. Making connections between past and present will help us better understand how to live and make decisions in a globalized world defined by constant change.

courses.title: Design Systems
courses.description: Students will employ effective visual communication strategies and adopt a user-centered methodology to craft aesthetically compelling designs that cross media. This course prepares students for the dynamic shifts in the design industry through the acquisition of a comprehensive skill set, spanning both traditional and emerging design platforms. Learning focuses on the integration of design elements within diverse systems and cultivates capabilities in critical thinking and problem-solving.
courses.subject: Graphic Design & VisCom
courses.prereq: Take 1 course: GDV-100 GDV-110 GAA-105 IXD-200

courses.title: Navigating Information
courses.description: What makes an argument good or bad? What counts as evidence in our post-truth world? How can you understand and assess the truth value of a claim when you're not an expert? In this course you'll learn rhetorical strategies about how to examine arguments and types of evidence in different disciplines and fields of study. To help learn these strategies, you will do close readings of texts from a variety of disciplines in the liberal arts and sciences, popular culture, and social media.

courses.title: Mobile Device Forensics
courses.description: Students in this course will/earn how to properly identify, preserve, analyze, examine data and report on mobile device data. Students will also be taught how to effectivefy conduct investigations involving mobile devices. Content will include analog and digital telephone networks and technologies surrounding cellular technology. Concepts of off the chip extraction and analysis will be discussed. Content will include analog and digital telephone networks and technologies surrounding cellular technology.
courses.subject: Computer & Digital For

courses.title: Special Topics in DF
courses.description: The course will focus on a current topic of interest in the Digital Forensics industry. The topics may vary and change every time the course is run depending on current trends in industry.
courses.subject: Computer & Digital For
courses.prereq: FOR-120 or by permission of instructor.

courses.title: Family Violence
courses.description: This course provides an understanding of the psychological, social and legal factors related to child abuse/neglect and violent domestic relationships in America. Students will comprehend the root causes of family violence and the mutigenerational effects on its victims and society. They will identify the challenges of such acts for our criminal justice, social service and health care systems and  articulate sometimes contradictory societal and legal responses to family violence?including prevention efforts, protection and treatment services, legal strategies, and current legislation.
courses.subject: Criminal Justice

courses.title: Intro to Game Develop. Mgmt
courses.description: Students will learn about team interactions, software project management processes, tools, and technologies, through observation, reflection, role-play and hands-on software project management.  Students are introduced to project management as a discipline, compare various software project management methodologies, discover and reflect on individual strengths and practices, and apply the Agile methodology to game development using Scrum, including day-to-day techniques to lead a team to success without waste, technical debt or crunchtime.
courses.subject: Business & Management
courses.prereq: For Game Production Management Students only or by permission of SSB Associate Dean.  Complete EGD-100.

courses.title: Screenwriting I
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to  screenwriting. In seminar and writing workshop  style, students will read and discuss short and  feature-length screenplays, including their own  works-in-progress, as well as compare scripts to  their final films. Students will learn basic  structures of screenplays, character development,  conflict, dialogue writing, industry standards  for script formatting and ways to ignite their  creative spark. Students will complete one short  film script.
courses.subject: Filmmaking
